elements.title: Lea Ackermann (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Lea Ackermann (pictured), a German nun of the Missionary Sisters of Our Lady of Africa, fought against forced prostitution and sex tourism in East Africa?

elements.title: Turkey is the world's largest grower (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Turkey is the world's largest grower of hazelnuts, apricots, and oregano?

elements.title: John Snow Society (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the John Snow Society's Pumphandle Lecture ends with a ceremonial removal of the Broad Street pump handle and a visit to a pub?

elements.title: Korea Job World (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in Korea Job World, children can participate in career-experience scenarios to explore vocational paths?

elements.title: Takahiro Nishikawa (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that former Dreams Come True band member Takahiro Nishikawa opened a bar in his hometown of Sapporo in 2009, seven years after he left the band?

elements.title: Morris–Jumel Mansion (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a manuscript discovered in the Morris–Jumel Mansion was sold for US$912,000 to finance the mansion's endowment fund?

elements.title: Joshua Sacco (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Zimbabwean musician Joshua Sacco and his band used to perform songs at ZANU–PF election rallies before he became a party member?

elements.title: Butts: A Backstory (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that The Washington Post called Butts: A Backstory "cheeky"?
